description.narrative: After more than ten years of war Syrian civil society is fragmented, both inside and outside Syria. At the same time political processes related to the future of Syria and processes that intend to pursue justice and accountability are internationally dominated and lack meaningful participation of Syrian citizens. The programme aims to support Syrian civil society – outside of Syria – to develop into an inclusive and non-violent peace movement that takes an active role in transitional processes and in promoting peace in Syria.

On one hand it provides civil society organisations (CSOs) with support to develop their non-violent strategising skills, their advocacy skills and their ability to build connections and bridges with various actors and communities within Syrian Civil Society at large. On the other hand it facilitates access to relevant in country authorities and international fora, so that concerns and interests of civilians will be heard in political and transitional processes.

The activity is part of a larger programme implemented by the Strengthening Civil Courage Alliance, consisting of ABAAD – Resource Center for Gender Equality, Amnesty International The Netherlands, DefendDefenders, PAX and their partner networks.
The programme primarily works with Syrian Civil Society and with and for victims and survivors of human rights violations, with a special focus on women and youth.

participating-org.narrative: ABAAD – Resource Center for Gender Equality

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 19318 3501 DH Utrecht The Netherlands

sector.narrative: Civilian peacebuilding, conflict prevention and resolution
Women’s rights organisations and movement, and government institutions

title.narrative: # of CSOs included in SPs (Strategic Partners) programmes (women-led)

comment.narrative: 1 CSOs are youth-led organizations building capacities of youth and promoting their participation in developing democratic processes promoting non violence and peace building. They contribute to developing relationships and dialogue between youth from diverse backgrounds. While both organizations have engaged in advocacy and have good networks in Europe to share messages, little contribution is made by constituencies in developing messaging. Another CSO is a women led organization ensuring that voices and experiences of women in displacement and rights violations contribute to developing policies.

2 CSOs will enhance the level of inclusion of youth from diverse backgrounds within their work. Their advocacy work will be strengthened in order to ensure that messaging is developed based on the collection of evidence and with participation of their members/constituencies. Another CSO will continue working with women and ensure their experience in displacement contributes to formulating messaging and influence policies. New partnerships with groups putting at heart the use of non-violent strategies and with a core mission of building a culture of non violence will be sought.

2 CSOs will enhance the level of inclusion of youth from diverse backgrounds within their work. Their advocacy work will be strengthened in order to ensure that messaging is developed based on the collection of evidence and with participation of their members/constituencies. Another CSO will continue working with women and ensure their experience in displacement contributes to formulating messaging and influence policies. New partnerships with groups putting at heart the use of non-violent strategies and with a core mission of building a culture of non violence will be sought.

title.narrative: Output 1.1.2 - Syrian partners have the knowledge and skills to develop and implement evidence-based advocacy strategies
# of advocacy initiatives implemented by CSOs with their members/constituencies

comment.narrative: CSOs implement a number of advocacy initiatives but with no or poor inclusion of members/constituencies and collected evidence
CSOs develop advocacy initiatives based on collected evidence and inclusion of members/constituencies

title.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives implemented by CSOs with their members/constituencies

comment.narrative: CSOs implement a number of advocacy initiatives but with no or poor inclusion of members/constituencies and collected evidence

title.narrative: Outcome 1.3 UN member states have supported the creation of an international process/instrument for the protection of the HLP rights of displaced Syrians.
# of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/ or creating space to engage

comment.narrative: HLP rights and demographic engineering have been raised in policy documents by relevant actors such as the EU and the Brussels Conference Co-Chairs, but have not translated into concrete actions
Demands shared by CSOs on HLP rights are translated into concrete actions by relevant actors

title.narrative: Outcome 2.1 International policymakers have an increased understanding of the long term impact on civilians in Syria from conflict, including on the use of explosive weapons in populated areas, drones and the linkages environment, peace and security through our research publications and outreach activities.

# and description of advocacy initiatives carried out by PAX and partner CSOs for, by or with their membership/ constituency (e.g. presentations during side events and pannel events for (inter)national policy makers and practitioners, policy briefs or reference to publications in national and international debates and/or media outlets)

comment.narrative: The report by AIrwars and PAX was referenced in parliamentary debates in the Netherlands, as well as covered in a national newspaper. It was also presented to Belgian, French, UK and German parliamentarians, as well as used as advised study material in the Utrecht University, and was shared widely on social media. In general there is widespread awareness about civilian harm on Syria, but there is a lack of attention to indirect and longer term harm, and it is not so much directly linked to the international policy debates on explosive weapons in populated areas.
Through the increased understanding of civilian and environmental harm from conflict we aim to increase the incentive and urgency for policymakers to address this harm.

title.narrative: # of CSOs with increased L&A capacities (youth-led)
